examples: I stretched the rubber band until it almost broke.
The rubber band stretched almost to the breaking point.
First, stretch the skin over the frame of the drum.

definitions.definition: To get more use than expected from a limited resource.
examples: I managed to stretch my coffee supply a few more days.
To say crossing the street was brave is stretching the meaning of "brave" considerably.
To say he's been to this park a million times is stretching the numbers. The true number is around 30 or 40.

definitions.definition: To extend physically, especially from limit point to limit point.
examples: The beach stretches from Cresswell to Amble.

definitions.definition: To extend one’s limbs or another part of the body, for example in order to improve the elasticity of one's muscles.
examples: Cats stretch with equal ease and agility beyond the point that breaks a man on the rack.
I always stretch my muscles before exercising.
When the cat woke up, it yawned and stretched .

definitions.definition: To extend to a limit point
examples: His mustache stretched all the way to his sideburns.

definitions.definition: To stretch the truth ; to exaggerate .
examples: a man apt to stretch in his report of facts

definitions.definition: To sail by the wind under press of canvas.
examples: The ship stretched to the eastward.

definitions.definition: To make great demands on the capacity or resources of something.
examples: Her bizarre explanation really stretches credulity.

secondary_definitions: ( figuratively , transitive ) To get more use than expected from a limited resource.
( figuratively , transitive ) To make inaccurate by exaggeration .
( intransitive ) To extend physically, especially from limit point to limit point.
( intransitive , transitive ) To extend one’s limbs or another part of the body, for example in order to improve the elasticity of one's muscles.
( intransitive ) To extend to a limit point
( obsolete , colloquial ) To stretch the truth ; to exaggerate .
( nautical ) To sail by the wind under press of canvas.
( slang , transitive , archaic ) To execute by hanging .
( transitive ) To make great demands on the capacity or resources of something.
